content.description: Left of two climbs on a large boulder just off the trail in the Standard Deviation area.  The climb zig zags to find the weaknesses to the top.  Good body positioning is required to get you up this one.
content.protection: TR bolts.  4th class around the left side of the boulder to reach the anchor.

content.description: Right of Turkey Chute.
content.location: A bit hidden and very simple, walk further to the right of Turkey Chute to find this little route.

content.description: This is the dihedral directly south of As the Crow Flys. The climb is actually 5.6 except for the bouldery move getting into the dihedral. This is a good intro to crack climbing. The crack takes good gear the whole way and there are great feet on either side of the dihedral. Newer (as of March 2020) two bolt anchor at the top of the dihedral (not to be confused with the anchor at the top of the ledge to the left for As the Crow flies). There are several top rope problems that can be done on either side of Turkey Chute ranging from 5.6-5.9
content.protection: .75-3 cams Bolt anchor and rap rings. There are two additional bolts directly on top of Turkey Chute with an easy walk off if you choose not to rap. Anchor access is almost directly across from the start of Abacab/Standard Deviation.

content.description: Your average Limbo 5.7 except for a no-feet section left of the arete if you choose to go that way. There are a number of ways to tackle this one, from face to arete.
content.protection: TR
content.location: This is the arete/face climb to the immediate right of "As the Crow Flies" (face) and to the immediate left of "Turkey Chute" (dihedral)

content.description: Flaring dihedral sitting on top of a ledge.  A few ways to get to the ledge exist.  Once there head straight up the dihedral.  Mostly stemming.  No real crux, just fun climbing all the way up.
content.protection: There are safe ways to the ledge.  I would say that the first placement that I would actually consider falling on after that comes maybe in the middle of the dihedral or higher.  If you are determined to lead this the dihedral protects with marginal RPs and probably good small aliens.  These are my observations from the safety of a TR anyway.  There is a bolt anchor at the top of this climb, maybe 20 feet back from the top which can be walked to up and left of the climb.  Only lead this if you don't mind soloing a little 5.10 because that's what you will be doing.
content.location: In the middle of the Limbo Area.  Just off the trail, to the right of The Rift.  An obvious wide dihedral that starts on a ledge.

content.description: This is a must do for the new leader. The route has 4 bolts. There is a horizontal crack 15 feet from the ground that will take a .75 cam if you feel uncomfortable climbing to the first bolt. The crux comes on the top half of the climb. Once you hit a large ledge you clip the third bolt and do a side pull on to a large foot hold. The climbing is good and straight forward. This is a fun quality climb. To get to The Tower from the ramp walk south on the loop trail for 125 yards you'll see the tower with four bolts. Anchor access for top rope can be had by walking on climber's loop past Turkey chute and taking a left up to the wall where Abacab is then keep moving up and left past the anchor for Turkey chute to a small down scramble to the top of the tower.
content.protection: 4 quick draws medium size cam optional. 2 bolt anchor with chains up on the top of the tower. Recommend extending your anchor over the edge.

content.description:
One of the best splitters at The Gorge. Arguably better than Craig's Crack but not quite as difficult. Nonetheless the climb, jams, rock quality and positioning are stellar.

If only all the rock at The Gorge was this good!
content.protection: Two bolt anchor. SLCD to size #2.
content.location:
Located directly above Skyline pinnacle, one tier up.

Just left of History Book.

Compliments of Neal Harder: "The best approach is to continue uphill past History Book until you are almost to the top, then cut right on a small ramp that leads to the top of an obscure route called Khyber Squirrel. From there you can easily reach the TR anchor, or drop down to the base of the formation."

climbs.name: Standard Deviation
climbs.fa: FTR: Jim Neff & Ed George 1979  FL: Art Messier 1999

content.description: "Balancy and steep face climbing. Left or right finish option from the 3rd bolt. lLeft finish is 5.10a, right finish is 5.9"- taken from Art Messier
content.protection: 4 bolts
content.location: On the Deviation Wall with Abacab, Back to Basics, Deviate Behavior, and Kathy's Memorial.

content.description: Start directly under the bolt visible high on the face. Move above the bolt and toward the thin left crack at the top. Walk about 7ft past the top out to find the anchor bolts.
content.protection: Gear. One bolt on face. Two bolt anchor at the top with quicklinks to rappell.
content.location: Above Aqualunge, Escape from the Underworld, and Apostrophe. As you hike to the ledge above those climbs, you will pass this one.

content.description:
A very obvious line to the left of Vawter's Dihedral.  A wide water polished crack that splits the rock all the way to the top.  Full of features and smaller internal cracks so this is not an actual wide crack climb in the sense of technique.

A mildly overhanging crux start on polished rock leads to easier, yet still challenging climbing ahead.
content.protection: Route protects very well.  Small to medium nuts and cams.  Mind your pro at the start, it is a matter of protection over handholds which forces the leader to make smart decisions.  Bolt anchor at the top, but a walk off (left).
content.location: Limbo area, left of Vawter's Dihedral.  Between two sport climbs.  A wide crack on water polished rock leads to a chimney topout.

content.description: Climb the face right of the History Book dihedral, topping out onto the ledge just left of the V. Traverse right and around the corner to finish up the slab. It looks like this climb was once sport bolted then chopped, so you can easily follow the empty bolt holes if you're not sure where to go.
content.protection: Top rope anchor bolts and links to rap.
content.location: On the same formation as History Book.

content.description: Follows the right side of the arete just left of Top of the Pops.
content.protection: Top rope anchor bolts and links to rap.
content.location: The obvious arete on the same formation as Top of the Pops.

content.description: Bouldery start leads to easy slab for the second half.
content.protection: Top rope anchor bolts and links to rap.
content.location: On the same formation as Top of the Pops, but around to the face left of the arete.

content.description: Start off with an overhang and then a cruxy lieback on classic Mission Gorge feet which leads to easier ground.  Great fun with good stances.  Too bad the second half isn't as interesting as the first.
content.protection: 4 bolts to a bolt anchor.  First bolt can be clipped by easier ground to the right before you start the overhang section for added safety.
content.location:
A little ways uphill from the climber's loop trail at the far right end of the Limbo area.  Just right of an obvious offwidth "Back to Basics".

Standard Deviation, also 5.10b is the last bolted climb up the hill from Monkey Dance and is also worthy of attention.

content.description: This begins in the short right-facing dihedral, about 10 feet left of Mighty Monger.  Climb up the dihedral almost to its end, which could be pushed over, then make a committing wide step to the right.  Continue up the shallow chimney/inset to the top.  Jeana followed my lead on Feb 23, 2016.  I'm sure that people had previously toproped this.
content.protection: SR, including tiny, small and medium cams.  Bolted anchors are on top.
content.location: This is the leftmost route in the face that includes The Rift.

content.description:
Sport climb just left of The Rift.  Blocky slick ground leads to a few cruxy lieback and other moves to top out.  Can bail to the right at the top if the crux is proving too difficult.

Bolted protection.  Bolt anchor.  Best to walk off climbers' left.
Face moves lead to a small roof with a crack. Pull hard through the roof and finish up easy ground to a bolted anchor. Anchor can be accessed by scrambling up around the left of Abacab.
content.protection: Small cams. 1st placement is high. Might be big enough for a small cam, maybe a nut would be better. 3 bolt anchor at top with 2 chains and rap rings.
content.location: Left of an obvious offwidth in the Standard Deviation area.

content.description: Fun face directly left of Craig's Crack. Follow the seams and arete on very nice, textured rock up using the small pockets and crimps. The crux is made up of a few powerful moves getting from the face to the large jugs two-thirds up the climb. Great follow up from facial tissue, as you can use the same anchor, and similar style of climbing. Nicely makes for a fun climbing session with a few friends.
content.protection: Use the TR from Craig's
content.location: Face directly to the left of Craig's crack, use small crack and arete.

content.description: This is the arête between Cake Walk and Baby Dehedral.  This route is a weird one with sloapers and pinchers.  Resist the urge to hug the whole rock, it'll stalemate ya.
content.protection:
Top rope only, theres a bolt mid-route, but its rusted and useless.

Two anchor bolts with links on top.
content.location: The arête between Cake Walk and Baby Dehedral

content.description: A fun low angle dihedral. Climb a short face to get into the dihedral then stem and climb up edges to the top. Due to its location high on the hillside it feels very exposed.
content.protection: #0.3 to #0.75. Nuts. Some placements for micronuts.. Rappel anchor at top left.
content.location: Hike up the gully between the True Skyline Arete and the Limbo Area. History Book is on the looker's right side of the gully and starts from a narrow grassy ledge. If you get to Top of the Pops then you've hiked too far up the gully.

content.description: Standard Mission Gorge face climb, definitely worth doing after you lead Craig's Crack.
content.protection: Build an anchor above Craig's.
content.location: The face directly to the right of Craig's Crack.

content.description: Sport route to the right of the Rift. A bit of a puzzler but the moves are there. More challenging then Mighty Monger. Variety of ways to get off the ground, with only one realistic path above.
content.protection:
Quickdraws

Lies in between 'The Rift' and 'Vawter's Dihedral'

content.description: This thing starts off hard and doesn't really ease up until the end.  Starting the route takes interesting body language and the route then continues up lots of crimpers.  The sustained nature of this route makes it quite difficult for the rating.
content.protection: 5 Bolts.  TR can be set on bolt anchor by scrambling to the left of the route.
content.location: Up on the hill. Head up from the base of The Rift/Mighty Monter/Vawter's Dihedral.

content.description:
Noticed this one in the Kennedy/Hubbard guidebook. I have not climbed it. It merges with Standard Deviation and therefore has two possible finishes (see photo).

Messier describes it as "Devious and technical."
content.protection: 5 bolts with a bolt anchor.
content.location: It begins in between Standard Deviation and Kathy's Memorial.

content.description: Route goes up the right side of the arete between Indecision and Baby Dihedral. Start is shared with Baby Dihedral. Continue climbing up the arete using the face to the right for some ok holds.
content.protection: TR only
content.location: Between Baby Dihedral and Indecision.

content.description:
Probably the most jammable crack at The Gorge.  Great hand jams on sticky rock all the way up.  The top gets a little wide, but not too bad.  I would liken it to an easier version of The Robbins Crack.  It is slightly longer than Robbins too!  Would be an area gang-roped classic if its location were more obvious.

There are at least two other climbs on the same rope for a TR.  Make sure your rope does not get pinched in the top of the crack like another's has.  There was a bee hive near here not long ago, watch out for them.
content.protection: Cams 0.5 to #3 make this route well-protected. Set a gear anchor (I used BD #3, 0.75, and 0.5), walk off back.
content.location: At the top of the hill.  Really it's own area.  Head uphill past Monkey Dance and Standard Deviation.  This is just right of Turkey Chute and you will end up passing the top of this climb.  Head to the top of the hill to a pinnacle with an obvious hand crack.  You can see this pinnacle on the skyline from the road.

content.description:
Definitely falls in the category of 'worth doing if your in the area'

Very short, but provides those who have hiked up to Craig's Crack a third pitch of climbing. If you would free solo "The Chimney" on the main wall you would have no problems doing the same here.
content.protection: Can be top roped with some modifications to anchor built for Craig's Crack
content.location: Right of Craig's Crack, very obvious chimney.

content.description: A large low angle dihedral that faces up hill.  Good route for trad gear learning.  There is a chockstone in the crack for slings, para cracks for cams, and wedged cracks for nuts.  This is a good way to get to the top for other climbs.
content.protection:
Slings for stones wedged in the crack, #2 and .5 Camalot. (Or scramble.)

Shares anchor bolts/links with Indecision
content.location: Easy looking route to the direct right of the bolted 5.10b Monkey Dance.

content.description: Walk up the ramp to the right, then follow the crack moving up and left. When you reach the right-side crack near the top, follow it straight up.
content.protection: Small cams and nuts. One old, rusted, and bent piton. Two bolt anchor with quicklinks at the top (shared with Sloppy Seconds).
content.location: Above Aqualunge, Escape from the Underworld, and Apostrophe. Walk farther uphill like you're scrambling to the anchors of those climbs and you will pass right by this one.

content.description: A mostly finger sized crack whose business starts right off the deck.  Almost feels like a sport climb with some initial powerful and balancy moves.  Once past the crux, follow sustained 5.9 moves up to the roof where you traverse right a little and finish up a short offwidth.
content.protection: Mostly smaller gear, but the anchor is best with ~3.5" pieces, so take some along.  The clear crux is between the first and second protection pieces.  The crux is hard and insecure.  There is high potential for a short groundfall if you fall on your way to your second piece.  A toprope can be had if you feel unfomfortable leading this.
content.location: Up the hill past Vawter's Dihedral area but below Apostrophe.  A short cliff with a small roof.  The roof is split into a very short offwidth section.  Can walk around to get off or set a toprope.

content.description:
Starting as you would Vawter's Dihedral, continue up the excellent short crack that leans right. Where the crack ends, traverse about eight feet to the right, above a muddy drop-off.  Climb straight up, into an alcove.

I belayed in the alcove, so I could communicate with Beke (pronounced "bee-key") , who had not previously climbed outside.  From here, you can climb over the bulge that defines the alcove, or scramble left (exposed) to the anchors above Vawter's Monger.

BTW Beke climbed this more easily and quickly than I did. Along with his friend Yonk, we toproped the Rift, etc.  Date: Feb 17, 2016.
content.protection: The crack eats the hand-sized that feeds it. Protecting the traverse took some thought and effort. Bring a #4 to protect or anchor in the alcove.
content.location: Start as for Vawter's Dihedral.

content.description:
Right of two climbs on the large rounded boulder at the bottom of the Standard Deviation area.  Just off the main trail.

Climb up features to the right of a pod.  Reachy positive moves lead you to reachy thin moves.  As the angle slacks off, the holds get thinner.
content.protection: TR bolts.  4th class around the left side of the boulder to reach the anchor.

content.description: This "classic" wide crack/offwidth is listed as 5.6 in both the county guide and the online PDF. My thoughts differ but I am interested in what others have to say.  Shares an anchor with Kathy's Memorial which can be accessed by scrambling up around the left of Abacab.
content.protection: You would need some WIDE stuff. 3 bolt anchor with 2 chains and rap rings.
content.location: Most obvious offwidth crack on the Standard Deviation wall. Right of Kathy's Memorial.

content.description: Short hand crack dihedral. A fun way to the anchors above the Standard deviation wall. Would also make a good first lead for someone with a small rack.
content.protection: Hand pieces, medium to large hexes would work well. Sling-able chockstones too... Plenty of ways to learn to place gear. Bolt Anchors at Top
content.location: Right section of Standard Deviation Wall.  Closer to main Climber's Loop trail. Stands out as obvious Dihedral

content.description: As the Crow flys is directly south of The Tower. This fun sport route is straight forward with good hands and feet. There are four bolts that are reasonably spaced. The crux comes after the third bolt. There is a stemming lie back on a large flake. The climb finishes on a large ledge. You can start the climb from the ground or scramble up to the ledge below the first bolt.
content.protection: 4 quick draws Bolt anchor with rap rings

climbs.name: Aqualunge
climbs.fa: Galen Kirkwood, Frank Noble, Mike Paul 1976

content.description: This route starts out moderate but increases in difficulty really quick.  The meat of the climbing heads up a leftward slanting seam that provides holds about as well as it provides gear.  There's a reason it's bolted.  Old school 11a.
content.protection: 2 Bolts.  You wouldn't want to fall in the wrong place on this route.  For mortals we can toprope (bolts) it without too much difficulty by scrambling up left of the route.  There are a couple of potential gear options for the lead but I have never paid them much attention on TR.
content.location: Up on the hill.  Head up from the base of The Rift/Mighty Monter/Vawter's Dihedral.

content.description: A good top rope problem that could be lead. Gear placements exist until the balancy transition onto the easy face portion in the second half of the climb. Definitely wouldn't want to fall from the top on lead, but the upper portion is a cake walk.
content.protection: Top rope bolt anchors exist. Small gear placements exist in the first 15ft
content.location: Far left of Standard Deviation Wall look for the sharp zig zag flakes

content.description: Climb up a short textured pillar to the top, transition left into the crack and continue climbing up through an offwidth finish.
content.protection: Standard rack. Bolt anchor. Rappel station.
